H0.text: The Moon blocks the Earth from the Sun when a solar eclipse occurs.

H1.text: The first four planets in the solar system are aligned when a solar eclipse occurs.

H2.text: Earth blocks the Moon from the Sun is what occurs during a solar eclipse.

H3.text: Earth's shadow falling on the Sun is the event that constitutes a solar eclipse.

A4.text: A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between Earth and the Sun, thereby obscuring the view of the Sun from a small part of Earth, totally or partially.

A5.text: The Moon's orbit around Earth is inclined at an angle of just over 5 degrees to the plane of Earth's orbit around the Sun (the ecliptic). Because of this, at the time of a new moon, the Moon will usually pass to the north or south of the Sun.

A6.text: A total solar eclipse occurs when the Earth intersects the umbra portion of the Moon's shadow.
